data.title: 172 Things to Do in Philly This Week and Weekend
data.meta_description: Looking for things to do in Philadelphia? Find the best shows, events, festivals, concerts, things to do with kids, and happenings in Philly.
data.text:
P!nk comes to town, a vegan festival, Fabrika celebrates Brat Summer, the Philadelphia Folk Festival returns, and Manayunk goes to the dogs.

Festivals, Food & Other Fun Stuff

MUSIC/FESTIVAL

Philadelphia Folk Festival

After an unfortunate hiatus, the beloved and sorely missed Philadelphia Folk Festival makes its triumphant return this weekend. Come back to the farm for three busy days of music up in Schwenksville, featuring John Oates, Gangstagrass, Turtle Ridge, Theo Kandel, Jess Klein, John Flynn, Lenny Kaye and lots more. It’s not just a music thing, it’s also about food, drinks, crafts, art, and general good vibes.

$100-$120 per day; $250 for all three days, August 16th-18th, Old Pool Farm, 1323 Salford Station Road, Schwenksville.

BEER

Parks on Tap

Under a blazing sun and across parched soil, Parks & Rec’s itinerant beer garden ceaselessly drags its taps, tables and grills to a new park each week. This week? Pennsport’s Dickinson Square, a sweet green parallelogram in Pennsport/South Philly that is sometimes referred to as Dickinson Square Park, because nobody cares about anything anymore and the Lord has left us here. (That’s my Falling Down issue, Philly people who say “Square Park.”)

Pay as you go, August 14th-18th, Dickinson Square Park, 1600 East Moyamensing Avenue.

CONVENTION

Philadelphia Oddities & Curiosities Expo 2024

A two-day convention for “lovers of the strange, unusual & bizarre” full of vendors, displays, “preserved specimens, original artwork, horror/Halloween-inspired pieces, antiques, handcrafted oddities,” etc. For something more hands on, you can pay extra to take classes in Entomology/Bug Pinning, Rat Taxidermy and Jackalope Taxidermy. The dead don’t need their bodies no more.

$12-$15, August 17th & 18th, 10 a.m., Greater Philadelphia Expo Center, 100 Station Avenue, Oaks.

FOOD/SHOPPING

The Southeast Asian Market

Every weekend, vendors from area Lao, Khmer, Thai, Vietnamese and Indonesian communities sell food and ingredients FDR Park. In addition to the many cuisine options, you can pick up produce, clothing, jewelry, etc. Psst: Get yourself a savory stuffed chicken wing.

Pay as you go; Saturdays & Sundays through October; 10 a.m.-6 p.m., Franklin Delano Roosevelt Park, 1500 Pattison Avenue.

PETS/SHOPPING

Manayunk Pet Month

In August, Manayunk’s “shop, dine, and stroll” motto adopts a pet theme. By pet, we just mean “dog,” right? Nobody’s bringing their cats out for a trot down Main Street. Or maybe you’ve got a parrot or a snake? They seem to travel okay.

August 15th: Pet Bandana Making with Portable Picasso a screening of Honey, I Shrunk the Kids at JD McGillicuddy’s at dusk. Hell yeah, get your snake a bandana.

August 17th: Dog Day of Summer, an all-day celebration where dogs and dog owners can check out vendors, entertainment, treats, yappy hours, and more.

August 22nd: Canine Caricatures & Movie Night, featuring Dan’s Toonz and Moana at JD McGillicuddy’s at dusk.

August 29th: Pup Cup Buffet featuring peanut butter & bacon treats and all natural peanut butter.

Free till you spend money, starts 5 p.m., Main Street, Manayunk.

OUTDOORS

The Oval

Philadelphia’s Favorite Traffic Island (seasonal category) is back, with a summertime slate of activities and attractions including a beer garden, food trucks, art installations, live music, movies, games and such. Friday: Modero & Company performs Indonesian dance. Saturday afternoon:West African dance and music by Troupe Da Da. Saturday night: Music bby Olivia K & The Parkers. Sunday: Family Fun with The Clay Studio, and later, Quizzo with Johnny Goodtimes. The Oval!

Free, continues through August 25th, in and around Eakins Oval, 2451 Benjamin Franklin Parkway.

See Also: What to Expect at the Oval Pop-Up on the Parkway This Summer

FOOD/DRINK

PHS Pop-Up Gardens

Is it beer garden season, people. The Pennsylvania Horticultural Society hosts two pop-up gardens: on South Street and in Manayunk.

Pay as you go, through late fall; PHS Pop-Up Garden at Manayunk, 106 Jamestown Avenue; PHS Pop-Up Garden at South Street, 1438 South Street.

See Also: Philly’s Best Kid-Friendly Beer Gardens

TOUR/ART

Summer aBroad Augmented Reality Tour

Use your smartphone to take an interactive tour of sites in and around North Broad Street, including the Rail Park, the Divine Lorraine Hotel, the Historic Blue Horizon, the Leon H. Sullivan Charitable trust and Sea Abroad Experience, the Historic Sullivan Progress Plaza and the Uptown Theater.

Free, through August 31st, North Broad Street.

OUTDOORS/DINOSAURS

Summer of Dinos

Morris Arboretum is overrun with dinosaurs as well as Plants in the Age of Dinosaurs. Take a self-guided tour of the grounds and enjoy the outdoor miniature train is displays set 66-252 million years ago.

Included in $20 admission, through September 30th, Morris Arboretum, 100 East Northwestern Avenue.

LIGHTS

Philadelphia Chinese Lantern Festival

Every year, Franklin Square angers the ancient ones with this glorious and brazen display of electricity, which includes among its illuminated attractions a fiery 200-foot-long dragon. This is the year of the dragon, BTW. Besides the lantern displays, there’s juggling, acrobatics, dancing, music, food, a beer garden, mini-golf, a fountain show and more.

$25, through August 18th, 6-11 p.m. nightly, Franklin Square, 200 North 6th Street.

See Also: Your Guide to the Philadelphia Chinese Lantern Festival in Franklin Square

KIDS/FISH

Now Swimming @ Adventure Aquarium

SpongeBob SquarePants‘ 25th Anniversary Adventure Aquarium hosts an immersive “SpongeBob experience” including photo ops, an episode screening, worksheets and more. Through September 15th.

Shark Summer It’s hot shark summer, baby. Or cold, maybe? Point is, Adventure Aquarium has you covered with behind-the-scenes tours, the 81-foot suspended Shark Bridge, shark trivia, touchable sharks, and a visit from the magical Scuba Tooth Fairy who dives in among the sharks to scoop up teeth. What does she do with the teeth? Don’t ask. Through August 18th.

Included in $28-$48 admission, Adventure Aquarium, 1 Riverside Drive, Camden.

On Stage

COMEDY

Sarah Sherman

The Squirm returns. Sarah Sherman is the resident mischief maker on SNL, providing the show’s weirdest, loudest laughs. It’s especially funny to watch her peck away at Colin Jost.

$26-$44, August 15th-17th, Helium, 2031 Sansom Street.

THEATER

Grease

Bucks County Playhouse presents a new production of the beloved musical by Jim Jacobs and Warren Casey. Directed by Hunter Foster. Choreography by Alison Solomon. “Summer days drifting away, to uh, oh those summer nights.”

$32-$72, through September 8th, Bucks County Playhouse, 70 South Main Street, New Hope.

COMEDY

Michael Longfellow

Dude’s got some gall coming to town the same weekend as his fellow SNL cast member Sarah Sherman. Bully move, bro. I mean he’s funny. But like what a psycho, right?

$32-$44, August 16th & 17th, Punch Line Philly, 33 East Laurel Street.

MUSIC

PartyNextDoor

The Canadian producer/R&B artist released his fourth eponymous record in April, and its rather NSFW cover raised quite a commotion. For the record, the model — a PND fan who goes by MaamiNextDoor — likes the way it looks. Live your dreams. PartyNextDoor’s next record will be a collaboration with Drake.

$232-$892, August 12th & 13th, 8 p.m., Fillmore Philly, 29 East Allen Street.

THEATER

I Love the ’80s to Death

“Big-name musicians are gathering for a big concert, but backstage tensions are high. Secrets are spilling out with, like, totally tragic results.” A murder mystery dinner presented by the Murder Mystery Co.

$77, August 16th & 17th, 7-9:30 p.m., Cock ’n Bull Restaurant Route 263 & Street Road, Lahaska.

Movies

Now Showing @ Film Society Center

As always, the Film Society has a busy schedule this week, with lots of first-run and reparatory fare. We’ve listed one-off screenings under their individual days, but here are some films showing more than once this week.

Ghost in the Shell (Mizuho Nishikubo, Mamoru Oshii, 1995). $15.50; August 16th at 10 p.m. and August 17th a 9:15 p.m.

La Haine (Mathieu Kassovitz, 1995). $15.50; August 16th at 7 p.m. and August 17th at 7 p.m.

Secret Sunshine (Lee Chang-Dong, 2002). $15.50; August 17th at 3 p.m. and August 18th at 6 p.m.

Film Society Center, 1412 Chestnut Street.

The Women’s Film Festival

Ten days celebrating “work by and about women” kicks off on August 15th with an opening night reception and film screening at the Art Museum. The rest of the screenings take place at Christ Church — full schedule here.

$8-$125, August 15th-25th, Neighborhood House at Christ Church, 20 North American Street.

Back To The Woods: A Blair Witch Project

This two-day fan event at the beloved Mahoning Drive-In features DJs, themed raffles, and nightly screenings of the 1999 low-budget found-footage horror classic I legit thought might be real somehow even though I was an adult, but what can I say? It was pre-Google and I’m gullible. Each night also each night is followed by a “thematically creepy second feature.”

$13.24-$23.44 per day, August 16th & 17th, 6-11:30 p.m., The Mahoning Drive-In Theater, 635 Seneca Road, Lehighton.

Free Outdoor Movies This Week

August 14th: Dodgeball @ Libertee Grounds

August 14th: Wonka @ Cira Green

August 14th: Back to the Future @ Matthias Baldwin Park

August 15th: Transformers: Rise of the Beasts @ Triangle Park

August 15th: Wish @ Williams Moore Reed Memorial Park

August 15th: Kung Fu Panda @ at Rainbow de Colores Park

August 15th: Wonka @ Schuylkill Banks

August 15th: Barbie @ Peddler’s Village

August 16th: Jumanji (1995) @ The Oval

August 16th: Wonka @ Clark Park

August 17th: 42 @ FDR Park

August 17th: Kung Fu Panda @ 3rd & Norris Playground

August 17th: FernGully: The Last Rainforest @ Cira Green

August 18th: Short Circuit @ Spruce Street Harbor Park

Free, multiple locations.

See Also: Where to Watch Free Outdoor Movies in Philadelphia This Summer

50 Years in the Making

The Clay Studio continues its semi-centennial celebration with this exhibition of works by 140 alumni from its resident artist, guest artist, and associate artist program.

Free, through September 1st, The Clay Studio, 1425 North American Street.

In Pursuit: Artists’ Perspectives on a Nation

The National Liberty Museum examines “the power of art as civic dialogue” in its latest multi-media group exhibition featuring sculptures and large-scale installations by Anila Quayyum Agha, Angel Cabrales, Nicholas Galanin, Arghavan Khosravi, Aram Han Sifuentes, Artur Silva, and Marisa Williamson.

Continues through October 28th, $12 museum admission, National Liberty Museum, 321 Chestnut Street.

Now Showing @ the Art Museum

Take a Seat: Understanding the Modern Chair — modern chairs from the permanent collection. Ongoing.

Expanded Painting in the 1960s and 1970s — radical innovations in painting by Alma Thomas, Sam Gilliam and more. Ongoing.

Collecting Japanese Art in Philadelphia — Drawn from the works highlighted in the new publication Art of Japan: Highlights from the Philadelphia Museum of Art. Ongoing.

Mythical Creatures: China and the World, explores diversity by comparing mythical creatures in different cultures. Through June 1st, 2025.

Mary Cassatt at Work — The PMA presents the first major showing of the Pennsylvania-born French Impressionist artist’s oeuvre since 1998-99. Through September 8th.

Seeing with Empathy: The Female Gaze in American Modernism, ongoing.

El Origen de la Noche (The Origin of Night) — 4Direcciones Audiovisual “working in collaboration with a group of traditional authorities from indigenous communities of the north-west Amazon” presents this immersive sound installation directed by Diana Rico and Richard Decaillet. Through September 15th.

Mysteries, Copies and Forgeries. Through November 18th.

Jesse Krimes: Rikers Quilt — The Philly artist presents his work which combines “painting, textiles, sculpture, installation, and advocacy.” Through September 15th.

$14-$23 admission, Philadelphia Museum of Art, 2600 Benjamin Franklin Parkway.

John Jarboe: The Rose Garden

The trans artist presents “a multi-room domestic environment reimagining John’s gender journey.” The Rose Garden is an “immersive maze of memories and provocations” full of video sculptures, music, objects and more. Read more here. Through September 29th.

Free (suggested donation $5), Fabric Workshop and Museum, 1214 Arch Street.

Now Showing @ Michener Art Museum

George R. Anthonisen: Meditations on the Human Condition The Michener hosts a career-spanning exhibition of works by the accomplished sculptor, including 40 bronze sculptures, maquettes, and frescoes, inside and outside the museum. Through October 14th.

Monuments and Myths Subtitled The America of Sculptors Augustus Saint-Gaudens and Daniel Chester French, this new exhibition at Michener explores the artists’ “intersecting biographies and examines the affinities that made both of them leaders in their field.” Through January 5th.

$15 museum admission, Michener Art Museum, 138 South Pine Street, Doylestown.

Now Happening @ the Museum for Art in Wood

The Poetry Gumball Machine Project — Poet and “multiform artist” LindoYes, the project is more or less what it sounds like, a mechanized sculpture that dispenses poetry stuffed inside little walnut shell capsules. The PGMP will be on display at the Museum for Art in Wood through the rest of the year. Through December 31st.

Experiencing Form: Phil Brown and the Museum’s Residency Artist Alumni, group show. Through September 15th.

Fruition: Windgate Arts Residency Program in Wood 2024, The Museum for Art in Wood’s annual summer group exhibition includes works by Chance Coalter, Jamie Herman, Jodie Prud’homme, Sara Tabbert, Molly Nemer, Sarah Watlington, Brittany Rudolf, Folayemi Wilson and Melissa Engler. Through October 20th.

Free admission, Museum for Art in Wood, 141 North 3rd Street.

Now Showing @ the Barnes

Matisse & Renoir: New Encounters at the Barnes — This new exhibition arranges 34 works by the boundary-pushing artists in a way that emphasizes their art-historical context. Runs through September 8th.

Education & Empowerment: Scholarship Recipients at the Barnes Foundation, 1927-1949 — Includes archival materials by Paul B. Moses, Ablyne Lockhart, Dr. DeHaven Hinkson and Aaron Douglas. Through August 15th.

Visions, group exhibition of works by artists from Mural Arts Philadelphia’s Guild program and SCI Phoenix. Through August 26th.

Museum admission is $23-$30, Barnes Foundation, 2025 Benjamin Franklin Parkway.

Entryways: Nontsikelelo Mutiti

The Zimbabwean-born visual artist and educator was invited to reimagine the windows on the ICA’s facade.

Free, through December 31st. Institute of Contemporary Art, 118 South 36th Street.

Every Leaf & Twig: Andrew Wyeth’s Botanical Imagination

The Brandywine Museum hosts this Andrew Wyeth exhibition focusing on “the fragile rhythms and intimate dramas of plant life,” and includes 40 watercolors and drawings, many of which have never been exhibited before. Through September 15th.

$18-$20, Brandywine Museum of Art, 1 Hoffman’s Mill Road, Chadds Ford.

Museums

Constructing Knowledge

Subtitled 300 Years of The Carpenters’ Company of the City and County of Philadelphia, this longterm exhibition at the Athenæum celebrates three centuries of bringing architects, contractors and engineers together like finely fitted joists. Now, you may be thinking: Are not Philadelphia the city and Philadelphia the county the same thing? Are they not, in a word, coterminous? Look, you wanna pick a fight with a 300-year-old gang of carpenters, that is your business. Not my table.

Free, through August 30th, the Athenæum Of Philadelphia, 219 South 6th Street.

The Sweetest Side of Life: Swedish Candy & Confections

The Swedish Museum in FDR Park hosts this pop-up exhibition featuring “the collection of Tyler Graybeal, owner of Sweetish-Swedish Candy and Goods.” Googled it. He’s a real person! His collection includes tins, wrappers, bottles, postcards and more. Swedish sweets are available for sale, too.

$15 admission, through September 15th, American Swedish Historical Museum, 1900 Pattison Avenue.

Witness to Revolution: The Unlikely Travels of Washington’s Tent

This exhibition will “bring to life the stories of individuals from all walks of life who saved Washington’s tent from being lost over the generations and who ultimately fashioned this relic into a symbol of the fragile American republic.” Includes art, artifacts, rare documents and the tent itself.

Included in museum admission of $13-$22, through January 5th, Museum of the American Revolution, 101 South 3rd Street.

Now Happening @ the Academy of Natural Sciences

Under the Canopy: Animals of the Rainforest — This new special exhibit includes “interactive discovery stations, dynamic displays and engaging programming” surrounding the importance of rainforests and the plants and animals that live there. Through September 2nd.

Life Onto Land: The Devonian — An exhibition on the life and ecosystems of the Devonian period, the geological era during which creatures wriggled up on dry land, which everybody agrees was a solid move with a lot of potential. Through September 29th.

The Doan Gang: Outlaws of the Revolution

The Mercer Museum’s immersive exhibition tells the story of Revolutionary War-era loyalists. “Learn how these local outlaws plotted, schemed, and plundered their way through a divided world in the earliest days of a budding American nation, and why their deep loyalty to British rule in the colonies made them enemies of the Founding Fathers.”

$15, through December 31st, Mercer Museum, 84 South Pine Street, Doylestown.

The Art of the Brick

Time’s running out to check out this exhibition of “inspiring artwork” — bricked-up versions of Starry Night, Mona Lisa, etc. — made by LEGO master Nathan Sawaya. Plus a 9,000-square-foot brick play space.

$20-$43, through September 2nd, Franklin Institute, 222 North 20th Street.

Wild Kratts: Creature Power

At the Please Touch Museum, kids can tap into their “creature power” with a special exhibit based on the PBS series Wild Kratts. Little ones can investigate four different interactive habitats and learn about the animal world with games, movement and problem-solving.

$22, through September 1st, Please Touch Museum, 4231 Avenue of the Republic.

BOLD: Color from Test Tube to Textile

This new exhibition at Old City’s Science History Institute explores the complicated history and science of natural and synthetic dye-making “drawing on dye sample books, vivid clothing, and scientific instruments.” Through August.

Free admission, Science History Institute, 315 Chestnut Street.

Outdoors

Festival of Fountains

Flowers and greenery are usually the focus of a trip to Longwood Gardens, but this annual summer show is all about the waterworks. And the lights. And there’s some mood music, too. Timed admission tickets are required, so plan your visit ahead of time.

$32, continues through October 27th, Longwood Gardens, 1001 Longwood Road, Kennett Square.

Summerfest

There’s no roller-skating this summer, but there will be games of chance, mini-golf, a Ferris wheel, food, drinks and a nice view of the Delaware River to boot.

Pay as you go, ongoing, 101 South Christopher Columbus Boulevard.

Spruce Street Harbor Park

The lovely and popular Spruce Street Harbor Park returns for another summer of lights, hammocks and action along the Delaware. Also: food, drinks, ice cream, barges, chairs and a general feeling that we can have nice things.

Free unless you spend money, ongoing, 301 South Christopher Columbus Boulevard.

See Also: Your Guide to the Delaware Waterfront This Season

Andalusia Historic House, Gardens & Arboretum

The 50-acre historic estate along the Delaware River is open for self-guided tours of its formal gardens and native woodlands. Picnics encouraged.

$15, through November 8th, Andalusia Historic House & Gardens, 1237 State Road, Andalusia.

Click here to jump down to the weekend.

MONDAY, AUGUST 12th

ARTS

Fringe Festival Preview Night

The big festival’s not till September, but you can catch a sneak peek with these eclectic preview events every Monday night this month. August 12th’s shows include What Is The Butt Game?, Self Help | Panopticon, LoveBot: A Musical and more. But seriously: What is the Butt Game?

Pay what you can, 7-8 p.m., FringeArts, 140 North Columbus Boulevard.

SCIENCE

Science on Tap, Untapped

Science on Tap celebrates 15 years of social and scientific get-togethers with Legendary Science, a program that focuses around Loch Ness Monster, Kraken, Bigfoot and more. This event description confirms their existence. Speakers include: Kelsey Manahan-Phelan (Academy of Natural Sciences), Ali Rospond (American Philosophical Society), Brigitte Keslinke (UPenn) and Lisa Geiger (Mütter Museum).

Free, 6-8 p.m., Science History Institute, 315 Chestnut Street.

COMEDY

Shane Gillis & Friends

After coming up through the Philly comedy scene, standup/podcaster Shane Gillis was famously added to and ejected from SNL in the span of a few days back in 2019 (due to his offensive oeuvre). Gillis landed on his feet however, with several high profile gigs and shows, including hosting SNL last year, and a Netflix series called Tires. He’s bring some friends with him for this Monday night show at Helium.

Sold out, 7:30 p.m., Helium, 2031 Sansom Street.

MOVIES

Blood Sick Underground Cinema

This time, the monthly Blood Sick movie series at PhilaMOCA presents two locally made horror flicks on VHS: queer/occult romance Coven of the Black Cube and Busted Babies, “a cinematic tale of breakable proportions, within extra immortal cheeze and girls.” More info here.

$18.66, 7:30 p.m., PhilaMOCA, 531 North 12th Street.

FOOD

A Taste of Yucatán

Chef Juan Carlos Aparicio of El Chingon and chef Jason Peabody of Oloroso team up for one-night-only five-course dinners based on a “diverse selection of authentic and contemporary takes on Mexican gastronomy.” Optional wine and mescal.

$75, 5:30 and 8 p.m., Oloroso, 1121 Walnut Street.

More Monday Stuff

MUSIC: Krallice. $18, 7:30 p.m., Underground Arts, 200 Callowhill Street.

MUSIC: Oso Oso. $25, 8 p.m., Kung Fu Necktie, 1248 North Front Street.

MUSIC/TRIBUTE: Let’s Groove Tonight, Earth Wind and Fire Tribute. $20-$30, 7:30 p.m., City Winery, 990 Filbert Street.

MOVIES: Raising Arizona (Coen Bros., 1987). $15, 7 p.m., Bryn Mawr Film Institute, 824 Lancaster Avenue, Bryn Mawr.

COMEDY: Mom’s Mayhem Indie Improv Cage Match. Free, 7 p.m., Tattooed Mom, 530 South Street.

TUESDAY, AUGUST 13th

MUSIC

Kid Congo Powers & The Pink Monkey Birds

There will be a lot of concentrated cred on stage at PhilaMOCA on Tuesday when Kid Congo Powers — whose CV includes names Nick Cave & The Bad Seeds, The Cramps and Gun Club — takes the stage with his current band, The Pink Monkey Birds. All-woman, all-mom Ramones tribute act the Ramoms open the show.

$18.66, 8 p.m., PhilaMOCA, 531 North 12th Street.

<a href="https://kidcongothepinkmonkeybirds.bandcamp.com/album/swing-from-the-sean-delear">Swing From The Sean DeLear by Kid Congo & The Pink Monkey Birds</a>

STARGAZING

Park After Dark

Fairmount Park Conservancy hosts this two-mile guided moonwalk and telescope observation, led by astronomer/educator Buddy Muhler of the Academy of Natural Sciences. I believe by moonwalk they mean “moonlit walk.” I bet it’s still nice, though.

$15, 8:30-10:30 p.m., Lemon Hill Picnic Pavilion, Lemon Hill Drive.

MUSIC

Not Just Jazz Goes Country

Live music by Jason and the Tall Trees, plus line dancing, food, drinks and a mechanical bull. Presented by Friends of FDR Park.

Free to enter, 5-8 p.m., Boathouse at FDR Park.

BOOKS/ENVIRONMENT

Lifehouse: Taking Care of Ourselves in a World on Fire

Philly author Adam Greenfield discusses his new book about “community resilience in the face of climate catastrophe” in conversation with Glenn Wallis. FYI: “A Lifehouse is an institution at the heart of each neighborhood that responds to the terrifying reality of climate collapse in our own communities.”

Free, 6:30-8:30 p.m., Iffy Books, 404 Street 20th Street

KIDS

Parkway Pals

Sister Cities Park brings back its Parkway Pals series of free weekly kids’ programming. On Tuesday mornings, the Free Library of Philadelphia brings Story Art — interactive story and craft time — and the Fabric Workshop and Museum will keep the creativity going with “Art Garden.”

Free, 10:30 a.m.-12:30 p.m., Sister Cities Park, 210 North 18th Street.

More Tuesday Stuff

MUSIC: Wild Nothing, with Peel Dream Magazine. $27.50, 8 p.m., Underground Arts, 200 Callowhill Street.

MOVIES: Maestra (Maggie Contreras, 2023). $14, 1:30 p.m., Ambler Theater, 108 East Butler Avenue, Ambler.

ARTIST TALK: Sarah Gutwirth and Christopher Poehlmann. Free, 6-8 p.m., Oar Club, Park Towne Place, 2200 Benjamin Franklin Parkway.

COMEDY: Case Comedy. Free, 7:30-9 p.m., Abyssinia, 229 South 45th Street.

FITNESS: PHIT Body. Free, 6-7 p.m., Dilworth Park, 1 South 15th Street.

WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 14th

MUSIC

Friendship

The Philly band released an excellent record on Merge a couple years back called Love the Stranger. Friendship plays JB’s on Wednesday with Styrofoam Winos and Jacob Augustine.

$15, 7 p.m., Johnny Brenda’s, 1201 North Frankford Avenue.

MUSIC

Future

The Atlanta mumble rapper teamed up with St. Louis hip-hop producer Metro Boomin for two records so far this year, We Don’t Trust You and its instant sequel We Still Don’t Trust You. The pair have cancelled several shows on their We Trust You tour, but this Wednesday’s gig at the WFC is good to go.

$49-$199, 8 p.m., Wells Fargo Center, 3601 South Broad Street.

COMEDY

TaTa Sherise

The South Jersey-born comedian, actress and podcaster headlines a midweek show at Helium. More on TaTa Sherise here.

$20-$28, 8 p.m., Helium, 2031 Sansom Street.

MUSIC

Steven Page

The former Barenaked Ladies frontman these days performs as a member of the Trans-Canada Highwaymen and as a solo artist, his most recent record being 2022’s Excelsior. On Wednesday, Page plays a free show in a Jersey park, with Tom Hampton.

Free, 7:30 p.m., Haddon Lake Park, Hillside and South Park Avenue, Haddon Heights.

MUSIC

Jazz Jams with Orrin Evans

Philly pianist extraordinaire Orrin Evans hosts another Jazz Jam at WCL, this time featuring fellow pianist Neil Podgurski. As always, instrumentalists and vocalists are welcome to sign up and join in.

Free, 8:30 p.m., World Cafe Live, 3025 Walnut Street.

MUSIC

Lindsey Stirling

The pop classical violinist — and America’s Got Talent alum — is known for her confident, highly physical playing style, as documented on her popular YouTube channel. She was famously on the bill at this billionaire’s wedding at the pyramids. Canadian indie pop act Walk Off the Earth opens Stirling’s show at the Met.

$53-$223, 7 p.m., The Met, 858 North Broad Street.

MUSIC

Thirty Seconds To Mars

This long-running pop/rock band — featuring Jared Leto (formerly of The Frozen Embryos and Residue) and his brother Shannon Leto — wrote about 200 songs during the pandemic but ended up putting only 11 on 2023’s It’s the End of the World but It’s a Beautiful Day. The record does have 10 different covers, however. With AFI, Poppy and KennyHoopla.

$33-$151, 6:30 p.m., Freedom Mortgage Pavilion, 1 Harbour Boulevard, Camden.

KIDS

Parkway Pals

Sister Cities Park brings back its Parkway Pals series of free weekly kids’ programming. On Wednesday morning, the Academy of Natural Sciences brings its “Investigation Station” to the park.

Free, 10:30-11:30 a.m., Sister Cities Park, 210 North 18th Street.

More Wednesday Stuff

MUSIC: Tate McRae, with Presley Regier. $160-$420, 7:30 Mann Center, 5201 Parkside Avenue.

MUSIC: Dad Bod, with Oruã and cut//slack. $16.17, 8 p.m., PhilaMOCA, 531 North 12th Street.

MUSIC: Midge Ure, “Band in a Box Nth America 2024,” wit DJ Robert Drake. $25-$45, 8:30 p.m., City Winery, 990 Filbert Street.

COMEDY: Hannibal Thompson. $26-$36, 7:30 p.m., Punch Line Philly, 33 East Laurel Street.

COMEDY: Next In Line Comedy: Free F#ckin’ Comedy Show. Free, 7 p.m., Tattooed Mom, 530 South Street.

MOVIES: Between the Temples (Nathan Silver, 2024). $15.50, August 14th, 7:30 p.m., Film Society Center, 1412 Chestnut Street.

MOVIES: The Bridge on the River Kwai (David Lean, 1957). $15.50, August 14th, 7 p.m., Film Society Center, 1412 Chestnut Street.

DRINKS: Meet the Brewers: Summery Ciders with Dressler Estate. Free, 5-7 p.m., Drexel Gateway, 3161-67 Market Street.

THURSDAY, AUGUST 15th

MOVIES

Lake Michigan Monster

Before making this year’s indie word-of-mouth sensation Hundreds of Beavers, Mike Cheslik and Ryland Brickson Cole Tews teamed up on 2018’s Lake Michigan Monster, an entirely different ambitious but low-budget horror-comedy flick. I shall not attempt to summarize!

$14.93, 7:30 p.m., PhilaMOCA, 531 North 12th Street.

MUSIC

Candlelight: Magical Movie Soundtracks

The Listeso String Quartet presents a night of Hollywood favorites by candlelight at Adventure Aquarium. Includes favorites from The Little Mermaid, The Lion King, Beauty and the Beast, Aladdin, Cinderella and more.

$66.50-$80, 6 & 8:30 p.m., Adventure Aquarium, 1 Riverside Drive, Camden.

MUSIC

John Oates

The pop/soul veteran presented “An Evening of Songs and Stories” in Cape May that doubles as a warm-up show before this weekend’s Folk Fest.

$60, 8-10 p.m., Cape May Convention Hall, 714 Beach Ave, Cape May.

MUSIC

New Kids on the Block

The Boston-based boy band is still hanging tough after all these years, and are playing the WFC on Thursday with Paula Abdul and DJ Jazzy Jeff. So, what the hell, let’s play Two Truths and a Lie with New Kids on the Block.

NKOTB have sold more than 80 million records, and have a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame.

NKOTB released their eighth record, Still Kids, in May.

NKOTB member Danny Wood was replaced with a robot in 1989 so the real Danny Wood could pursue his hobby of roughin’ up weirdos in Southie full time.

$20-$502, 7 p.m., Wells Fargo Center, 3601 South Broad Street.

OUTDOORS/SHOPPING

Passyunk Passeggiata

This “Italian-style promenade” features happy hour specials and sidewalk shopping every Thursday over the summer.

Pay as you go, Thursdays, 5-7 p.m., East Passyunk Avenue.

OUTDOORS/MUSIC

Third Thursday at Glen Foerd

Gather on the lawn for live music by Samantha Rise, lawn games, food trucks, and an arts and crafts table. There will also be free self-guided tours of the historical mansion.

Free, 6-8:30 p.m., Glen Foerd, 5001 Grant Avenue.

MOVIES

QTPOC Film Screening Night: Conjuring Joy

A screening of short films created by Philadelphia queer and trans artists. Also: talkbacks some of the filmmakers and light refreshments.

Free (donations accepted), 7-9 p.m., Painted Bride West, 5212 Market Street.

MUSIC

Lady Alma @ Vertical Current

Philly house music queen Lady Alma plays this free outdoor show in University City. With DJ AfrVbz.

Free, 5-8 p.m., Lawn at uCity Square, 3701 Filbert Street.

MUSIC

The Lower Aetna

The indie rock/country Philly band just celebrated the release of their second record Pine; at press time they’ve only freed up a couple tracks on Bandcamp, but from the get-go I appreciate gentle scratch in Dylan Gallimore’s voice and the band’s overall rustic drama vibes. The Forest View Movement and Steady Hands open this show.

$15-$20, 8:30 p.m., World Cafe Live, 3025 Walnut Street.

<a href="https://theloweraetna.bandcamp.com/album/pine">Pine by The Lower Aetna</a>

More Thursday Stuff

MUSIC: Shallow Alcove. $20, 8 p.m., Johnny Brenda’s, 1201 North Frankford Avenue.

DANCE PARTY: Y’allternative, emo/country from Sad & Boujee & Rodeo Disco. $16, 9 p.m., Underground Arts, 200 Callowhill Street.

KIDS: Parkway Pals. Free, 10:30 a.m.-12:30 p.m., Sister Cities Park, 210 North 18th Street.

FRIDAY, AUGUST 16th

MUSIC

Taking Back Sunday

Last year, the wily rock veterans released 152 — their eighth record and first in seven years. This number appears on all of Taking Back Sunday’s albums and is, according to some guy on Reddit, a reference to a highway exit near the North Carolina home of singer/guitarist Adam Lazzara. But then other Redditors were like, that’s not true, and … I stopped skimming after that. None of which should distract you from the band’s true origins in Amityville, Long Island, New York, where that crazy haunted house was or is? And does this mean Taking Back Sunday is themselves haunted? Yes. Citizen opens the show, and they should be on the lookout for flies and numerology.

$80-$264, 8 p.m., Fillmore Philly, 29 East Allen Street.

FLOWERS/BEATLES

Magical Mystery Tour

This evening event at Longwood Gardens includes special tours of Peirce’s Park and Chimes Tower, plus live performances of Beatles music both on the famous organ in the Conservatory Ballroom and by the Beatles tribute band Minas in the beer garden. The evening ends with “Get Back: The Beatles” as performed by the sentient water which inhabits the Illuminated Fountain.

$32, 5-10 p.m., Longwood Gardens, 1001 Longwood Road, Kennett Square.

OPERA

Opera on Tap Philly Goes to the Movies

Philly Opera singers perform the music of classical and opera music we know through “films, TV, cartoons, or other pop culture.” It’s kind of an intimate space for all this vocal power. Should be very memorable.

Free, 7 p.m., Dahlak Paradise, 4708 Baltimore Avenue.

MUSIC

All the Living and the Dead

There’s lots to love about the new self-titled record by Philly band All the Living and the Dead: catchy choruses, solid rock guitars, and peppy power pop vibes. But most of all I’m digging the layered, lush, lovely, boy-girl vocals. With Mesmer and Dark Arc.

$15, 7:30 p.m., Kung Fu Necktie, 1248 North Front Street.

<a href="https://allthelivingandthedead.bandcamp.com/album/all-the-living-and-the-dead">All the Living and the Dead by All the Living and the Dead</a>

MUSIC

Ryan Adams

The veteran singer-songwriter and Whiskeytown frontman plays an intimate solo show at the Keswick. Just for fun, check out this Reddit thread “Sad Songs written about Ryan Adams.” It’s probably out of date by now. But you gotta appreciate a singer so often sung about.

$49.50-$130, 8 p.m., Keswick Theatre, 291 North Keswick Avenue, Glenside.

MUSIC

Hootie & the Blowfish

Let’s play Two Truths and a Lie! Again? Yes!

Hootie & the Blowfish’s biggest hit was 1995’s “Only Wanna Be With You” which peaked at #6 on the Billboard chart.

Hootie & the Blowfish’s 1994 record Cracked Rear View has gone platinum 21 times.

In 2012, Darius Rucker wrote a best-selling parenting advice book entitled Let Her Cry: Stop Babying Your Baby: How to Tune Out the Tantrums: But When the Dolphins Make Me Cry, Please Hold Me.

Collective Soul and Edwin McCain open the show.

$28-$170, 7 p.m., Freedom Mortgage Pavilion, 1 Harbour Boulevard, Camden.

BEER GARDEN

Rodin Garden Bar

Chill out on Fridays all summer long within the confines of this romantic mostly open-air museum on the Parkway devoted to the famous French sculptor.

Free till you spend money, 4-8:30 p.m., Fridays, through August 30th, Rodin Museum, 2151 Benjamin Franklin Parkway.

DANCE/MUSIC

Philadanco / Bloodstone

Philly-based contemporary dance company Philadanco performs with R&B/soul group Bloodstone, known for “Natural High,” “Never Let You Go,” “Outside Woman” and ’70s hits. ’Danco will also pay tribute to their founder, Joan Myers Brown. Also on the bill: Manhattans featuring Gerald Alston, Blue Magic, and Lenny Williams.

$55-$80, 7 p.m., Dell Music Center, 2400 Strawberry Mansion Drive.

WRESTLING

Solar Slam

High Tension Wrestling and Pro Wrestling Explosion present a night of intense, independent matches in the cozy confines of PhilaMOCA. Featuring CC Boost vs. Dylan Mesh.

$20-$30, 7:30-11 p.m., PhilaMOCA, 531 North 12th Street.

MUSIC

Lindsay Reamer

The Philly field scientist-turned-musician celebrates the release of her debut full-length record Natural Science. Reamer apparently spent most of 2023 writing and recording this album while road-tripping across America and walking the earth. With Terra Cotta and Fernette.

$15, 8 p.m., Johnny Brenda’s, 1201 North Frankford Avenue.

<a href="https://lindsayreamer.bandcamp.com/album/natural-science">Natural Science by Lindsay Reamer</a>

SATURDAY, AUGUST 17th

MOVIES

The Human Condition Trilogy

On Saturday, the Film Society presents this acclaimed and controversial WWII trilogy by Japanese filmmaker Masaki Kobayashi.

The Human Condition I: No Greater Love (1959) @ 11:30 a.m.

The Human Condition II: The Road To Eternity (1959) @ 4 p.m.

The Human Condition III: A Soldier’s Prayer (1961) @ 8 p.m.

$15.50, Film Society Center, 1412 Chestnut Street.

MUSIC

Dierks Bentley

The Phoenix-born country bro/occasional country satirist is known for songs like “Drunk on a Plane,” “Beers on Me,” “What Was I Thinkin’,” “Different for Girls”, “Woman, Amen,” “Holistic Detective Agency” and more. With Chase Rice and Randy Rogers Band.

$27-$127, 7 p.m., Freedom Mortgage Pavilion, 1 Harbour Boulevard, Camden.

FOOD/MUSIC

Vegandale

I cannot tell you why Rick Ross is headlining this vegan food and music fest down by the Navy Yard. The rapper/record exec famously wears fur and owns chicken restaurants. The Vegandale people don’t seem to have an answer — asked about it in 2023 they said “[Rick Ross] may not be vegan … yet. But his thousands of fans coming to Vegandale might leave that way.” — but the concert series has apparently been happening for a while without incident. Not sure what kind of incident I’m imagining. It’s too hot to wear fur. Also on the bill: Saweetie, Polo G and lots of delicious-looking vegan food.

$30-$40 for the Foodie Experience, $60-$70 for Music Series + Foodie Experience, Marine Parade Grounds, Navy Yard, 4747 South Broad Street.

MUSIC

Nokosee Fields trio

Fire Museum Presents and nkwiluntàmën team up to present this free, outdoor performance by Nokosee Fields, “one of the most provocative, significant, and capable voices in the North American traditional music scene.” Plus a sound installation by Nathan Young.

Free, 2 p.m., Penn Treaty Park, 1301 North Beach Street.

WRESTLING

Revolt! Freedom! Passion!

Attic Brewing in Germantown hosts a night of independent, in-your-face wrestling. We’re talking Cheeseburger vs. Vita VonStarr; Hallowicked vs. Matt Makowski, Brooke Valentine vs. Shea McCoy and lots more.

$10-$20, 9 p.m., Attic Brewing Company, 137 Berkley Street.

MUSIC/ART

Smorefest Music Festival

Rapper/producer James Weldon’s big West Philly music/art/s’mores festival returns with another packed lineup on two stages: LaRussell, Kenya Vaun, Dramab2r, Sy Mosquuiat, Amir Ali, Fakefree KP, Arthur Thomas & the Funkitorium, Dejhha, Corey Lee, Rechel Raquel and lots more.

$60-$100, 3 p.m., World Cafe Live, 3025 Walnut Street.

SUNDAY, AUGUST 18th

MUSIC

P!nk

The pop superstar plays the biggest stage in her pretty-much home town, with Sheryl Crow, The Script and KidCutUp. So … how bout we play Two Truths and a Lie one more time!?

P!nk has appeared on four #1 hit songs: “Just Give Me A Reason,” So What,” “Raise Your Glass” and “Lady Marmalade.”

At age 14, P!nk performed in an all-girl group in Philly called Basic Instinct.

The 2007 movie Catacombs — about P!nk and Shannyn Sossamon fleeing a minotaur in the tunnels beneath Paris — is based on a true story.

$49-$319, 6:30 p.m., Lincoln Financial Field, 1 Lincoln Financial Field Way.

MUSIC

The Brian McKnight 4

The R&B singer is known for his powerful vocals on romantic R&B favorites from the mid and late ’90s, like “Back at One,” “One Last Cry,” “Crazy Love,” and “You Should Be Mine” (with Mase, not GnR).

$39-$90, 7:30 p.m., Keswick Theatre, 291 North Keswick Avenue, Glenside.
